lines.value: the armenian genocide was the forcible deportation and massacring of armenians during the government of the young turks from 1915 to 1917 in the ottoman empire
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: in november 1914 the ottoman empire went into the world war i on the side of the central powers
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: i̇smail enver who was then the minister of war launched a disastrous military campaign against russian forces in the caucasus in hopes of capturing the city of baku
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: his forces were routed at the battle of sarikamis and many more of his men froze to death
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: returning to istanbul enver largely blamed the armenians living in the region for actively siding with the russians
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: in spite of these obstacles the armenians thrived under ottoman rule
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: the armenians tended to be better educated and wealthier than their turkish neighbors who in turn tended to resent their success
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: this resentment was compounded by suspicions that the christian armenians would be more loyal to christian governments that of the russians who shared an unstable border with turkey than they were to the ottoman caliphate
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: in 1914 the ottoman empire's war office had already begun a propaganda drive to present armenians living in the ottoman empire as a liability and threat to the country's security
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: an ottoman naval officer in the war office described the planning:in order to justify this enormous crime the requisite propaganda material was thoroughly prepared in istanbul
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: [it included such statements as] the armenians are in league with the enemy
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: they will launch an uprising in istanbul kill off the [[committee of union and progressthe ottoman government moving quickly arrested an estimated 250 armenian intellectuals on the night of 24 april 1915
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: the acts of genocide against the armenians continued for 9 years until 1922 with around 388000 armenians remaining.the turkish massacres of armenians in 1894 1895 1896 and 1909 were still fresh in their minds
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: in the beginning around 1915-1916 armenians would be kicked out of their homes which would be claimed by turks
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: during a turkification campaign the government squads kidnapped children converted them to islam and gave them to turkish families
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: in some places they raped and forced women to join turkish harems or serve as slaves.women would mar their bodies with scars or burn a part of their face to be unfit to join a harem
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: muslim families moved into the homes of deported armenians and seized their property
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: at the same time the turks created a special organization which in turn organized killing squads or butcher battalions to carry out as one officer put it the liquidation of the christian elements these killing squads were often made up of murderers and other ex convicts
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: people were drowned in rivers threw off cliffs crucified and burned alive
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: i am confident that the whole history of the human race contains no such horrible episode as this
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: the great massacres and persecutions of the past seem almost insignificant when compared with the sufferings of the armenian race in 1915 henry morgenthau american ambassador to the ottoman empire 1913-1916
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: henry morgenthau
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: guenter lewy claims in his book,the armenian massacres in ottoman turkey a disputed genocide that there is not enough evidence of the young turk regime organizing the killings of armenians in the ottoman empire
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: according to lewy even though their fate in world war i proved tragic it was not a real genocide because there were no centrally organized and state sponsored premeditation and genocidal intention
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: a major obstacle for wider recognition of the genocide in the world is the official position of turkey which they state that there was no systematic attempt to annihilate the armenian population and the 1915 massacres were made because of the tehcir law and ww1
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: in december 2008 a group of turkish scholars launched an online petition for people who wanted to apologize for what happened

lines.value: the people who created the petition didn't use the word genocide instead they used the word the great catastrophe regarding the event

lines.value: many turks viewed the armenians as having been a threat to the ottoman empire in a time of war arguing that people of various ethnicities were killed during the violence

lines.value: most countries stopped using the gold standard in the 20th century

lines.value: a superlative in grammar is an adjective describing a noun that is the best example of a given quality

lines.value: in other words a superlative describes a noun that has more of some quality than any other

lines.value: other adjectives have no superlative form at all and the superlative is made simply by adding the adverb most before the adjective

lines.value: instead you say most fun and most interesting this way of making the superlative is used for almost all adjectives ending in ing like interesting fascinating disgusting or appealing

lines.value: iowa () is a state in the midwestern united states
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: its name comes from the ioway people one of the native american tribes that lived in iowa
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: iowa was a part of new france but was sold to the united states as part of the louisiana purchase
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: its settlers were mostly farmers iowa is part of the corn belt and is often known as the food capital of the world however iowa's landscape culture and economy are diverse with the economy changing in the second half of the 20th century to include many kinds of business
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: iowa has more than 3 million people
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: its capital and largest city is des moines
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: iowa became a state in 1846
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: it was the 29th state to join the united states
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: iowa is in the midwestern united states
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: to the north of iowa is minnesota to the west are nebraska and south dakota to the south is missouri and to the east are illinois and wisconsin
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: the eastern border of the state is marked by the mississippi river which runs between iowa and illinois
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: the western border is marked by the missouri and big sioux rivers
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: the northern border is a line 43 degrees 30 minutes north latitude
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: the southern border follows the northern border of missouri
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: iowa and missouri disagreed about the location of the iowa missouri border
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: this argument was ended by the supreme court of the united states in the 1896 case state of missouri v state of iowa after a standoff called the honey war
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: the border follows the des moines river for the far eastern part of the state and is at close to 40 degrees 35 minutes north for the rest of the state
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: iowa has 99 counties but 100 county seats because lee county has two
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: the state capital des moines is in polk county

lines.value: most of iowa is considered to be a plain

lines.value: the government of iowa has three branches similar to the federal government of the united states
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: the executive branch is headed by the governor currently kim reynolds r since may 24 2017
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: the legislative branch is the iowa general assembly composed of two houses the iowa senate and the iowa house of representatives
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: the judicial branch is headed by the iowa supreme court under the chief justice currently marsha ternus
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: there are two major political parties in iowa the iowa democratic party and the republican party of iowa as well as several unofficial third parties
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: no one party is in charge of the government ; the governor is a republican and the house has a republican majority under kraig paulsen but the senate has a democratic majority under mike gronstal

lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: iowa also produces more ethanol fuel than any other us state

lines.value: a vice president is someone who helps a president conduct his or her duties
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: a vice president also takes over if a president is not
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: in business and in government a vice president vp is below a president in rank

lines.value: vice is comes from latin meaning in place of

lines.value: in british english a vice president in business is called a director

lines.value: breathing is moving air in and out of the lungs
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: the air going in and out is called breath
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: if a person cannot breathe they will die
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: breathing helps people do two very important things adults breathe about 18 times a minute which is more than 25000 times a day
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: children breathe even faster
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: a part of the brainstem called the medulla oblongata controls breathing
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: groups of neurons in the medulla tell the breathing muscles when to breathe in when to breathe faster and when to breathe slower
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: the brainstem measures how much carbon dioxide is in a person's blood
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: if there is too much carbon dioxide the medulla tells the body to breathe faster
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: this helps the person breathe out the extra carbon dioxide
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: once the amount of carbon dioxide in the blood is normal again the medulla tells the body to breathe slower again
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: the body also measures the amount of oxygen in the blood
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: if there is not enough oxygen in the blood the medulla will tell the body to breathe faster to take in more oxygen
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: once there is enough oxygen in the blood the medulla will tell the body to breathe slower again
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: for a person to breathe certain muscles have to contract get tighter and relax at the right times
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: the special groups of neurons in the medulla tell these breathing muscles when to contract which makes a person breathe in and when to relax which makes a person breathe out
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: there are a few main groups of muscles that control breathing
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: the diaphragm is the main muscle that controls breathing
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: it is a sheet of muscle that runs along the bottom of the rib cage
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: when the diaphragm is relaxed it is shaped like a dome like a half circle
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: when the medulla tells the diaphragm to make the body breathe in the diaphragm pulls down and straightens out
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: this creates more room inside the chest and more room for the lungs to fill up with air
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: air comes into the lungs this is inhalation
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: when it is time to breathe out the diaphragm relaxes again and air leaves the lungs
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: about 60% 70% of a person's ability to breathe comes from the diaphragm
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: the diaphragm is controlled by a special set of nerves called the phrenic nerves
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: the medulla tells the diaphragm when to contract by sending messages through the phrenic nerves
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: because the diaphragm is so important for breathing the phrenic nerves are very well protected in the body
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: they are at the very top of the spinal cord near the neck
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: the intercostal muscles run between each rib
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: when a person needs to breathe in these muscles contract and pull the ribs upward
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: this creates more room inside the chest for the lungs to fill
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: when a person is resting the about 30% to 40% of their ability to breathe comes from the intercostal muscles
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: the intercostal muscles are controlled by the intercostal nerves
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: the medulla tells the intercostals when to contract by sending messages through these nerves
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: the intercostal nerves are not as well protected as the phrenic nerves
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: the intercostal nerves run along the thoracic spine which is in the upper to middle back and connect to the intercostal muscles
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: this means that if a person injured their thoracic spine they might not be able to use their intercostal muscles
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: they would then lose 30% to 40% of their ability to breathe
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: however since the nerves that control the diaphragm are much farther up in the spine and better protected the person would still be able to use their diaphragm to breathe
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: they would still have 60% to 70% of their ability to breathe
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: accessory muscles are muscles that a person uses only when they need extra help breathing
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: sometimes this is normal
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: for example if a person has just done a lot of exercise they may need extra oxygen
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: the medulla will tell the accessory muscles to kick in to make it easier for the person to lift their chest to create more room for the lungs to fill
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: the most important accessory muscles are the muscles in the chest abdomen and neck
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: however if a person has to use accessory muscles to breathe while they are resting this is a sign that they are not getting the oxygen their body needs
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: they may need medication extra oxygen given through a mask or even emergency medical treatment to help them breathe normally
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: for example people with asthma or chronic obstructive pulmonary disease copd often use an inhaler when they have trouble breathing
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: the inhaler puffs a medicine like albuterol down into the windpipe and into the lungs
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: this makes the air passages wider and helps the person breathe better than they could before
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: gibraltar is an overseas territory of the united kingdom
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: this means it shares the british king or queen and has the protection of the british armed forces
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: it is in southwest europe on the mediterranean sea
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: about 32000 people live there
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: they are called gibraltarians
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: gibraltar has always been important as a military base because this is where the mediterranean sea narrows to only 14 kilometres 9 miles at the strait of gibraltar
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: this meant that whichever country controlled gibraltar could see all ships that came into the mediterranean sea
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: gibraltar is most famous for the rock of gibraltar a 426 meter high limestone rock rising out of the sea
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: the rock can be seen for many miles
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: it is home to the barbary apes a type of tail less macaque which are the only wild monkey s in europe
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: gibraltar was named for a general who led the umayyad conquest of hispania
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: it belonged to spain between the years 1501 and 1704 and it was captured by a group of dutch and british marines during the war of the spanish succession 1704
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: in 1713 spain signed the treaty of utrecht
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: this treaty ended the war and said gibraltar would be british permanently
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: however according to this treaty if the crown of great britain ever wants to leave the territory the crown of spain will have a prior position in order to claim the sovereignty
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: ever since then spain has tried to get gibraltar back
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: augustus latin imperator caesar divi filius augustus 23 september 63 bc - 19 august 14 ad was the first roman emperor ruling from 27 bc until his death in ad 14
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: he led rome in its transition from the roman republic to the roman empire
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: octavian as he was originally called was the adopted son of the dictator of the roman republic julius caesar
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: octavian came into power in the second triumvirate
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: this was three men ruling over the roman republic mark antony lepidus and octavian
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: all three were loyal to julius caesar the assassinated dictator killed in 44 bc following his death a civil war broke out across rome between those loyal to caesar and the conspirators led by two of caesar's assassins brutus and cassius
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: at first octavian was the junior partner in the triumvirate
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: lepidus was more experienced in government and mark antony was a fine military leader
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: the triumvirate defeated brutus and cassius at the battle of philippi 42 bc largely due to antony's leadership
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: then they split the leadership of the republic three ways
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: antony took the east lepidus took spain and part of north africa and octavian took italy
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: antony followed in caesar's footsteps by going to egypt and becoming cleopatra's lover
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: they had three children together
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: his absence from rome allowed the intelligent octavian to build up support
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: the triumvirate broke up in 33 bc and disagreement turned to civil war in 31 bc antony was defeated by octavian at the naval battle of actium and then at alexandria
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: he committed suicide as did his lover cleopatra vii of egypt in 30 bc lepidus was sidelined blamed for a revolt in sicily and removed from government
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: he died peacefully in exile in circeii in italy in the year 13 bc.after winning the power struggle octavian was voted as emperor by the roman senate in 31 bc he took the name augustus which meant exalted
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: he ruled until ad 14 when his stepson and son in law tiberius became emperor in his place
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: during his reign some of those who were against his government were murdered especially those senators who wanted to keep the roman republic
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: he promised to make rome a republic again but instead proclaimed himself high priest pontifex maximus
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: many temples in the provinces set up statues of him as one of their gods
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: the name of the month august in english and most other european languages comes from him

lines.value: his main accomplishment was the creation of the roman empire a political structure that lasted for nearly five centuries more

lines.value: he first recruited and set up the praetorian guard

lines.value: longboarding is a form of skateboarding
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: instead of using a normal sized board the longboarder uses a board that is generally longer than a skateboard hence the name longboards can range from 33.5 all the way up to 42 there are some cases in which boards can be a lot longer all the way up to 60+
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: longboarding was invented by milterz.instead of skating on ramps and half pipes the longboarder can skate down long and steep hills turning carving back and forth across the hill's face to slow down as a skier would
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: the longboard is also much more efficient for cruising or simply getting around as longboards typically are faster more stable and less tiring to propel than short freestyle i.e trick boards
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: unlike a bicycle a longboard is less vulnerable to theft as one's board may be carried under one's arm or stashed in a coat closet at work.advanced longboarders may be seen sliding skidding sideways to slow their boards on really steep hills
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: special gloves incorporating a hockey puck like friction pad velcroed to the palm may be worn which assists in both balance and braking allowing one hand to be dragged on the ground
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: a lot of longbarders just make their own gloves from sections of sliced up cutting board epoxied to the palm and fingers of work gloves
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: on narrow terribly steep hills such as in san francisco for example there's not enough room to carve back and forth to keep one's speed down and bombing dashing downhill similarly could result in an accident or uncontrollably high speed and so sliding was invented by a california surfer
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: sliding is a difficult and advanced method of slowing a board though
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: while learning the slide full pads and a helmet are a must
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: during more ordinary city commuting the easiest and first braking skill one learns is simply to drag the toe or heel of one's rear foot on the ground
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: the trucks swivelling axles of a longboard turn far more freely than that of a freestyle board
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: one good way to learn how to ride a longboard is to find a roomy smooth flat area a plaza or parking lot say and to just cruise around
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: once the longboarder is feeling good and loose warmed up then he should take that rear foot been pushing with and try coasting without placing it back on the rear of the deck
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: just coast and notice how he actually can steer the board with one foot
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: notice too that one can go much faster if one keeps his body's weight balanced above the foot that remains on the board
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: by pumping with the arms and pushing only with the ball of the driving foot one go much faster and prevent ankle injuries
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: if one finds himself slamming his driving foot down on the pavement he will probably be in need of a rest
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: now he is ready to carve
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: carving is an action in which the rider leans back and forth slowing them down
lines.name: Simple English

lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: unlike skateboarding longboarding aren't to good for tricks all though one can still do them

lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: in those days people often travelled by horse and cart
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: his father made good quality carriages and he made plenty of money from his business
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: when arnold was seven he started music lessons

lines.value: when he was ten he was good enough to study the violin at the vienna conservatorium which was a special school for musical pupils
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: in 1881 he played a violin solo with a famous orchestra and famous conductor the vienna philharmonic under hans richter
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: the piece he played was the violin concerto by otto goldmark
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: soon he was offered the job of orchestral leader

lines.value: he stayed in that job for 50 years

lines.value: rose did other things as well as playing with the orchestra

lines.value: he gave violin lessons to talented pupils
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: he like to play string quartets and he got together with three other players to make up the rose quartet
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: they were very good and for more than half a century people said they were the best string quartet in europe
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: arnold's brother eduard was the cellist in the quartet
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: they played works by lots of composers especially haydn mozart and ludwig van beethoven
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: rose knew the composer johannes brahms and they played some of brahms's compositions when they had only just been written e.g the clarinet quintet for clarinet and string quartet
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: the rose quartet also knew the composer schoenberg and helped him to get well known by playing his music

lines.value: when he looked down at his feet he saw a mouse sitting there
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: arnold and his wife justine had a son and a daughter who both became musicians
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: they had plenty of money to live quite comfortably
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: minimalism is a way of making modern art or music that uses simple ideas sounds or shapes
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: it was most popular in america in the 1960s and 1970s
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: there are many different kinds of minimalism
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: sometimes a simple thing is repeated many times until it seems very complicated
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: today minimalism can be used to talk about many things such as design architecture poetry and movies
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: in music minimalism is a way of composing classical music which became popular during the second half of the 20th century
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: it is a way of composing by using a simple idea which is repeated many times
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: a minimalist piece of music usually takes a short idea which may be a melodic or a rhythmic pattern
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: this idea is then repeated many times but each time it changes slightly
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: sometimes this may be done by two or more instruments which start off by playing their notes or chords together but as one is going slightly faster than the other they gradually become out of sync not synchronized i.e not together then eventually they catch up with one another again
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: usually this music is tonal so that it is firmly in one key
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: a steady pulse is kept throughout the whole piece
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: composers who wrote minimalist music include steve reich b.1936 philip glass b.1937 and terry riley b.1935
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: other composers like john adams b.1947 have also used minimalist ways of composing but they combined these with other techniques so that their music is not just minimalist
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: minimalist music became popular in the 1960s and 1970s
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: minimalist composers started writing like this also because a lot of new music at that time was very complicated and hard to understand
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: it was often serial music which was atonal with no obvious melodies or ideas that were easy to remember
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: minimalist music is not necessarily simple
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: it can have a kind of hypnotic effect but this is part of what the composer wants
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: reich's clapping music just consists of hand : there is no melody
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: he was thinking of african drum music when he wrote it
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: two performers begin by clapping a rhythm together
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: after 13 seconds the second performer leaves out the first quaver eighth note and puts it at the end of the second bar measure
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: after another 13 seconds this happens again so that in the end the two performers are together again
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: this music has to be listened to in a different way from other kinds of music
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: minimalism in visual art sometimes referred to as literalist art and abc art emerged in new york in the 1960s
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: as a product it had much in common with earlier geometric abstraction and suprematism
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: the term minimalism was not generally embraced by the artists associated with it and many practitioners of art called minimalist by critics did not identify it as a movement as such
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: one of the first artists specifically associated with minimalism was the painter frank stella whose early stripe paintings were highlighted in the 1959 show 16 americans organized by dorothy miller at the museum of modern art in new york
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: the width of the stripes in frank stellas's stripe paintings were determined by the dimensions of the lumber visible as the depth of the painting when viewed from the side used to construct the supportive chassis upon which the canvas was stretched
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: the decisions about structures on the front surface of the canvas were therefore not entirely subjective but pre conditioned by a given feature of the physical construction of the support
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: in the show catalog carl andre noted art excludes the unnecessary
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: frank stella has found it necessary to paint
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: there is nothing else in his painting
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: these reductive works were in sharp contrast to the energy filled and emotionally charged expressionist paintings of willem de kooning or franz kline
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: they leaned more towards the controlled somber color field paintings of barnett newman and mark rothko
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: although stella received immediate attention from the moma show artists like kenneth noland ralph humphrey robert motherwell and robert ryman had begun to explore stripes monochromatic and hard edge formats from the late 50s through the 1960s
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: hummingbirds are small birds of the family trochilidae
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: they are among the smallest of birds most species measure 7.5-13 cm 3-5 in
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: the smallest living bird species is the 2 5 cm bee hummingbird
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: they can hover in mid air by rapidly flapping their wings 12 80 times per second depending on the species
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: they are also the only group of birds able to fly backwards
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: their rapid wing beats do actually
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: they can fly at speeds over 15 m s 54 km h 34 mi h
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: hummingbirds help flowers to pollinate though most insects are best known for doing so
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: the hummingbird enjoys nectar like the butterfly and other flower loving insects such as bees
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: hummingbirds do not have a good sense of smell instead they are to color especially the color red
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: unlike the butterfly the hummingbird hovers over the flower as it drinks nectar from it like a moth
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: when it does so it flaps its wings very quickly to stay in one place which makes it look like a blur and also beats so fast makes a humming sound
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: a hummingbird sometimes puts its whole head into the flower to drink the nectar properly
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: when it takes its head back out its head is covered with yellow pollen so that when it moves to another flower it can pollinate
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: or sometimes it may pollinate with its beak
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: like bees hummingbirds can assess the amount of sugar in the nectar they eat
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: they reject flowers whose nectar has less than 10% sugar
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: nectar is a poor source of nutrients so hummingbirds meet their needs for protein amino acids vitamins minerals etc by preying on insects and spiders
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: most hummingbirds have bills that are long and straight or nearly so but in some species the bill shape is adapted for specialized feeding
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: thornbills have short sharp bills adapted for feeding from flowers with short corollas and piercing the bases of longer ones
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: the sicklebills extremely decurved bills are adapted to extracting nectar from the curved corollas of flowers in the family gesneriaceae
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: the bill of the fiery tailed awlbill has an upturned tip as in the avocets
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: the male tooth billed hummingbird has barracuda like spikes at the tip of its long straight bill
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: the two halves of a hummingbird's bill have a pronounced overlap with the lower half mandible fitting tightly inside the upper half maxilla
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: when hummingbirds feed on nectar the bill is usually only opened slightly allowing the tongue to dart out into the nectar
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: like the similar nectar feeding sunbirds and unlike other birds hummingbirds drink by using grooved or trough like tongues which they can stick out a long way
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: hummingbirds do not spend all day flying as the energy cost would be prohibitive the majority of their activity consists simply of sitting or perching
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: hummingbirds feed in many small meals consuming many small invertebrates and up to twelve times their own body weight in nectar each day
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: they spend an average of 10 15% of their time feeding and 75 80% sitting and digesting
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: since hummingbirds are specialized nectar eaters they are tied to the bird flowers they feed upon
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: some species especially those with unusual bill shapes such as the sword billed hummingbird and the sicklebills are co evolved with a small number of flower species
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: many plants pollinated by hummingbirds produce flowers in shades of red orange and bright pink though the birds will take nectar from flowers of many colors
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: hummingbirds can see wavelengths into the near ultraviolet
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: however their flowers do not reflect these wavelengths as many insect pollinated flowers do
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: the narrow color spectrum may make hummingbird pollinated flowers inconspicuous to insects thereby reducing nectar robbing by insects
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: hummingbird pollinated flowers also produce relatively weak nectar averaging 25% sugars w w containing high concentrations of sucrose whereas insect pollinated flowers typically produce more concentrated nectars dominated by fructose and glucose
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: hummingbirds have traditionally been a part of the bird order apodiformes
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: this order includes the hummingbirds the swifts and the tree swifts
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: the sibley ahlquist taxonomy of birds based on dna studies done in the 1970s and 1980s have changed the classification of hummingbirds
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: instead of being in the same order as the swifts the hummingbirds were made into an order that only included themselves trochiliformes
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: their previous order apodiformes was changed to the superorder apodimorphae
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: this superorder contains the three families of birds which were in it when it was an order

lines.value: the great fire of london happened in central london 1666

lines.value: however it did not reach these districts

lines.value: it began just after midnight on sunday september 2 and grew very fast

lines.value: firefighters of the time usually made firebreaks by destroying buildings around the fire so it could not spread

lines.value: this did not happen soon lord mayo sir thomas bloodworth was not certain what to do

lines.value: by the time he ordered such measures it was too late

lines.value: the fire pushed north on monday into the center of the city

lines.value: some people thought that foreigners were setting the fires

lines.value: both countries were england's enemies in the a war that was happening at that time
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: it was close to setting fire to charles ii's court at whitehall

lines.value: he feared a london rebellion amongst the refugees who had lost their property

lines.value: reflection is the change in direction of a wave at a boundary between two different media so that the wave moves back into the medium it came from

lines.value: the most common examples include the reflection of light sound and water waves

lines.value: specular reflection is a mirror like reflection of light from a surface in which light from a single incoming direction is reflected into a single outgoing direction
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: in the diagram to the right a light ray is coming from the point p and meets at the mirror at point o the ray reflects at the point o outwards in the same medium towards point q reflection is measured relative to a line through point o that is at 90˚ to the mirror

lines.value: the angles made by the light ray shown in the diagram as ) must be equal

lines.value: both angles have to be equal whenever reflection occurs

lines.value: the domesday book is the record of the great survey of much of england and parts of wales completed in 1086 done for william i of england or william the conqueror
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: the domesday book also known as domesday or book of winchester was a record of all taxable land in england together with such information as would indicate its worth
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: as the scribes went round england they were protected by william's armed men
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: each group was led by a royal commissioner who took a list of standard questions
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: a jury of local nobility and citizens answered the questions
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: all answers were written down in latin
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: information was collected from the start of 1086 and working up into the complete volume started later that year
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: william died in 1087 before the writing up work was completed
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: william the conqueror wished to know the details of the land he had conquered england
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: he let his knights and barons have big areas of land and wanted rent money from them
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: the domesday book was a record of every farm village and house so that he knew how much rent he should get
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: only some small villages in the countryside are not in the book
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: major cities like london and winchester are also not in the domesday book perhaps because of their size or because not owning land the people could not be taxed
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: the domesday book gave the names of king william's friends and even listed the number of pigs on a piece of land
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: but it was not like a modern census
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: it did not give the names of all the people
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: it listed the heads of each but left out londoners monks nuns and anyone living in castles
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: in effect it listed only people he could get rent from and who might supply men to fight in his army
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: the domesday book is two volumes
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: one of the books was called great domesday and the other was called little domesday
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: the draft of the second volume little domesday was never worked up but no doubt was used for tax collection just the same
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: the domesday book got its name because its lists were so complete that it reminded people of the last judgment which people also call doomsday or domesday in christianity when lists of what people have done go before god for people to be judged

lines.value: plant pathology or phytopathology is the study of plant diseases

lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: not included are ectoparasites like insects mites vertebrate or other pests that affect plant health by eating plant tissues
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: plant pathology involves the study of pathogen identification disease cycles economic impact plant disease epidemiology plant disease resistance how plant diseases affect humans and animals and how to manage plant diseases
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: plant pathology is of fundamental importance to agriculture

lines.value: the big bang is a scientific theory about how the universe started and then made the stars and galaxies we see today
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: the universe began as a very hot small and dense superforce the mix of the four fundamental forces with no stars atoms form or structure called a singularity
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: then about 13.7 billion years ago space expanded very quickly thus the name big bang
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: this started the formation of atoms which eventually led to the formation of stars and galaxies
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: it was georges lemaitre who first noted in 1927 that an expanding universe could be traced back in time to an originating single point
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: the universe is still expanding today and getting colder as well
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: as a whole the universe is growing and the temperature is falling as time passes
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: cosmology is the study of how the universe began and its development
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: scientists who study cosmology agree that the big bang theory matches what they have observed so far
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: fred hoyle called the theory the big bang on his radio show
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: he did not believe the big bang was correct
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: scientists who did not agree with him thought the name was funny and decided to use it
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: scientists base the big bang theory on many different observations
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: the most important is the redshift of very far away galaxies
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: redshift is the doppler effect occurring in light
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: when an object moves away from earth its color rays look more similar to the color red than they actually are because the movement stretches the wavelength of light given off by the object
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: scientists use the word red hot to describe this stretched light wave because red is the longest wavelength on the visible spectrum
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: the more redshift there is the faster the object is moving away
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: by measuring the redshift scientists proved that the universe is expanding and they can work out how fast the object is moving away from the earth
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: with very exact observation and measurements scientists believe that the universe was a singularity approximately 13.8 billion years ago
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: because most things become colder as they expand scientists assume that the universe was very small and very hot when it started
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: other observations that support the big bang theory are the amounts of chemical elements in the universe
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: amounts of very light elements such as hydrogen helium and lithium seem to agree with the theory of the big bang
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: scientists also have found cosmic microwaves radiation
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: this radiation is known as radio waves and they are everywhere in the universe
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: this radiation is now very weak and cold but a long time ago it was very strong and very hot
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: it could be said that time had no meaning before the big bang
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: if the big bang was the beginning of time then there was no universe before the big bang since there could not be any before if there was no time
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: other ideas state that the big bang was not the beginning of time 13.8 billion years ago
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: instead some believe that there was a completely different universe before the big bang and it may have been very different from the one we know today
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: education is about teaching learning skills and knowledge
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: education also means helping people to learn how to do things and encouraging them to think about what they learn
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: it is also important for educators to teach ways to find and use information
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: through education the knowledge of society country and of the world is passed on from generation to generation
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: in democracies through education children and adults are supposed to learn how to be active and effective citizens
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: education may help and guide individuals from one class to other
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: educated individuals and groups can do things that the less educated cannot
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: there are different ways to categorize education for example by age or subject
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: one way is to divide it into formal education non formal education and informal education
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: formal education is usually in school where a person may learn basic academic or trade skills
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: small children often attend a nursery or kindergarten but often formal education begins in elementary school and continues with secondary school
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: post secondary education or higher education is usually at a college or university which may grant an academic degree
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: non formal education includes adult basic education adult literacy education or school equivalency preparation
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: in nonformal education someone who is not in school can learn literacy other basic skills or job skills
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: home education individualized instruction such as programmed learning distance learning and computer assisted instruction are other possibilities
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: informal education is less organized
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: it may be a parent teaching a child how to prepare a meal or ride a bicycle
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: people can also get an informal education by reading many books from a library or educational websites
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: this may also be called self education
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: many public schools provide a free education through the government
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: parents may send their own children to a private schools but they must pay for it
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: in some poorer places some children cannot go to school because their countries do not make education available in their countries or because their families do not have enough money or because the children have to work for money or because the society have negative prejudice on education for girls
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: there are primary schools and secondary schools
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: in many places they are government funded
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: colleges and universities usually charge tuition payments which may be very different in different countries

lines.value: the circulatory system is the body system that moves blood around the body consisting of heart and all blood vessels
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: blood vessels that take blood away from the heart are arteries
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: arteries divide into smaller arteries as they go away from the heart
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: the smaller arteries that connect to the capillaries are called arterioles
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: blood vessels that take blood towards the heart are veins
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: veins get bigger as they go towards the heart
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: the smallest veins are called venules
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: capillaries go between arteries and veins
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: capillaries are quite thin hence the name which comes from the latin capillus meaning hair so blood moves heart→artery→arteriole→capillary→venule→vein→heart
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: this is called circulation
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: there are two different circulations in the circulatory system
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: the systemic circulation is how blood goes to most of the body
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: the pulmonary circulation is how blood goes through the lungs
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: pulmonary means ¨about the lungs¨
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: this is how it works in mammals including humans
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: circulatory systems of other vertebrates differ somewhat
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: invertebrates are very different
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: blood that comes from the left side of the heart is full of oxygen and nutrients
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: nutrients are substances that your body needs to live like protein fat carbohydrates vitamins and minerals
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: the blood brings the oxygen and nutrients to your body
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: this blood in systemic arteries that is full of oxygen and nutrients is systemic arterial blood
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: it is sometimes just called arterial blood
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: the biggest systemic artery in the body is the aorta
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: this is the large blood vessel that comes out of the heart
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: smaller arteries branch off from the aorta
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: these arteries have smaller arteries that branch off from them
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: the smallest arteries turn into arterioles
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: the smallest blood vessels are capillaries
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: systemic arterioles turn into capillaries
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: the blood from arterioles goes into the capillaries
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: there oxygen and nutrients go out of the blood into the tissue around the capillaries
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: the blood also picks up carbon dioxide and waste from the tissue
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: the network of capillaries that brings blood to an area is called a capillary bed
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: on the other end of the capillary it turns into a venule
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: venules are the smallest veins
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: veins take blood back to the heart
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: as veins go back to the heart they merge and get bigger
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: the biggest systemic veins in the body are the vena cava
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: there are two vena cava
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: the inferior vena cava takes blood from the lower part of the body to the right side of the heart
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: in anatomy inferior means below the superior vena cava takes blood from the upper part of the body to the heart.(superior means above
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: this same movement of blood goes through the lungs in the pulmonary circulation
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: the blood that the vena cava vein takes to the heart is full of carbon dioxide
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: it has much less oxygen than systemic arterial blood
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: the right side of the heart pushes the venous blood into the pulmonary artery
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: the pulmonary artery takes blood to the lungs
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: in the lungs the blood goes through the pulmonary capillary bed
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: the capillaries that are in the lungs
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: here it gets more oxygen
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: it also drops off carbon dioxide
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: this is the opposite of what happens in capillary beds in the rest of the body
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: in the systemic circulation blood drops off oxygen and picks up carbon dioxide
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: after the pulmonary capillary bed the blood goes to the pulmonary veins
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: this pulmonary venous blood now is full of oxygen
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: the pulmonary veins take blood to the left side of the heart
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: then the blood goes to the systemic circulation again
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: an electron microscope is a scientific instrument which uses a beam of electrons to examine objects on a very fine scale
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: in an optical microscope the wavelength of light limits the maximum magnification that is possible
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: as electrons have a smaller wavelength they can achieve a higher magnification and can see very small objects typically around 1000 times smaller than those seen in an optical microscope
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: the outline of objects as revealed by the flow of electrons is changed into a picture using visible light for people to see
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: a beam of electrons is sent towards the specimen some electrons are reflected while some pass through
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: those that pass through are detected and used to form an image of the specimen at a magnification of about 500000 times
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: this microscope is more powerful than a light microscope
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: similar to a transmission electron microscope but the reflected electrons are detected
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: by measuring the reflected electrons some information about the surface of the specimen can be gathered
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: a narrow beam of electrons is moved across the specimen and a picture is built up piece by piece by detecting how the electrons are reflected or absorbed as it moves
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: it combines the high magnification of tem with the better surface detail of sem
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: it can be used to perform complex analysis on the specimen which cannot be done using tem alone
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: * scanning tunneling microscope

lines.value: the nanking massacre was a genocide that happened in nanjing china in 1937 during the second sino japanese war
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: it is also called the nanjing massacre the rape of nanking or the rape of nanjing
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: at that time nanjing was the capital city of the republic of china and its name was spelled nanking
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: in the second sino japanese war china was fighting the empire of japan as part of world war ii
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: japan was trying to take over china
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: on december 13 1937 the imperial japanese army reached nanking and the massacre began
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: the nanjing massacre lasted over six weeks
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: during this time soldiers of the imperial japanese army
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: during the six weeks of the nanjing massacre the imperial japanese army ija massacred between 40000 and 300000 people
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: it is difficult to know exactly how many people were killed in this mass murder because the ija burnt many bodies buried others in mass graves and dumped others in the yangtze river
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: because of this scholars and historians do not agree on exactly how many civilians were killed
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: p.1015 however historians agree that the imperial japanese army began massacring chinese civilians the day they entered nanjing
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: on that day john rabe a german businessman wrote in his diary we come across corpses every 100 to 200 yards
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: the bodies of civilians that i examined had bullet holes in their backs
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: these people had been [running away] and were shot from behind p.67 in another massacre japanese soldiers shot thousands of chinese people with machine guns
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: they left their bodies in a trench they named the ten thousand corpse ditch most historians think that more than 12000 people were killed in this massacre
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: the ija also massacred about 100 hui people a minority group in china who are mostly muslim
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: for the entire six weeks of the massacre the imperial japanese army kept killing chinese civilians
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: they killed in ways and often tortured their victims before killing them
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: for example in 1984 ex ija soldier kozo tadokoro admitted we used barbed wire to [tie] the captured chinese into bundles of ten and tied them onto racks
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: then we poured gasoline on them and burned them alive
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: i felt like [i was] killing pigs }} another ex soldier named nagatoni admitted that japanese soldiers tortured people to death by doing things like we were living in an age where we were taught that chinese were not human
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: the army used a trumpet sound that meant kill all chinese who run away we were taught from childhood in schools that chinese were like insects }}
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: during the massacre the japanese soldiers raped about 20000 women including children and the elderly
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: p.1012 soldiers would go from door to door searching for girls
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: when they found them they would take them and gang rape them
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: if anyone tried to stop the soldiers the soldiers would shoot them
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: p.77 right after they raped the women the japanese soldiers would often kill them sometimes by mutilating their sex organs
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: one survivor of the massacre said that sons were forced to rape their mothers and fathers were forced to rape their daughters
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: one group of soldiers gang raped a pregnant woman who gave birth only a few hours later the baby did not seem to be hurt
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: japanese soldiers also raped buddhist nuns and forced monks to rape women
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: on 19 december 1937 the reverend james m mccallum wrote in his diary i know not where to end
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: never i have heard or read such [[wikt:brutalityanother witness to the rapes in nanjing was robert o wilson
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: he was a surgeon at an american hospital in nanking
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: on december 15 and 18 1937 he wrote to his family:'last night the house of one of the chinese staff members of the university was broken into and two of the women his relatives were raped
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: two girls about 16 were raped to death in one of the refugee camps
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: in the university middle school where there are 8000 people the japs came in ten times last night over the wall stole food clothing and raped until they were satisfied }}
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: starting in 1931 an international law called the third geneva convention said it was illegal to treat prisoners of war in certain ways
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: it said these prisoners had rights for example the right to have a trial before being executed
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: however in august 1937 hirohito the emperor of japan had decided that he and the jia would not follow any international laws about how chinese prisoners of war had to be treated
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: right after the jia took over nanjing they started searching for ex chinese soldiers
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: they took thousands of young men as prisoners
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: some of these men were never soldiers the jia just they were
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: without any trials the jia took many of these young men to the yangtze river and killed them with machine guns
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: according to made by ex jia soldiers on december 13 and 14 1937 a unit of jia soldiers had taken 14777 chinese prisoners of war
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: in the next few days they took another 2000 3000 prisoners
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: in two days the jia massacred every one of these prisoners of war over 15000 people
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: in their confessions the ex jia soldiers said their military leaders had ordered them to do this
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: over the six weeks of the massacre the jia killed a total of about 30000 chinese prisoners of war
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: the japanese army left most of the buildings in nanjing destroyed by looting and arson
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: they destroyed newly built government buildings as well as many civilians homes
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: soldiers also stole whatever they wanted
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: because the imperial japanese army was so much stronger than the chinese soldiers and civilians in nanjing the chinese could not fight back
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: this meant the japanese could take all of the city's things for themselves
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: in january 1938 the japanese imperial army announced that nanjing was in order again
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: in the first week of february it created a government that would obey all of japan's needs

lines.value: the nanjing massacre is still very controversial in japan
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: only a small number of japanese writers say the massacre never happened at all
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: most of the argument over the massacre has to do with how many chinese people died
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: some scholars say that many fewer chinese people died than most historians say
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: for example japanese writer tanaka masaaki says that only a few hundred civilians died in nanjing
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: as of 2014 japan still honored fourteen class a war criminals including the three who were in charge of the nanjing massacre at a national shrine
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: in physics buoyancy () is a force on an object making that object rise or move upward
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: it comes from the spanish word for float boyar
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: buoyancy is made by the difference in pressure put on the object by the fluid or air that the object is in.the net upward buoyancy force is equal to the magnitude of the weight of fluid that is displaced by the body
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: this force enables the object to float or at least to seem lighter
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: buoyancy is important for many vehicles such as boats ships balloons and blimps
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: if the object has exactly the same density as the liquid then its buoyancy is the same as its weight
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: it will not sink or float
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: an object with a higher average density than the fluid has less buoyancy than weight and it will sink
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: that is why pebbles do not float
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: although a ship is made of steel which is more dense than water,it floats because it encloses a volume of air and the resulting shape has an average density less than that of the water

lines.value: a battery converts chemical energy into electrical energy by a chemical reaction
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: usually the chemicals are kept inside the battery

lines.value: it is used in a circuit to power other components
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: a battery produces direct current dc electricity electricity that flows in one direction and does not switch back and forth
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: using the electricity from an outlet in a building is cheaper and more efficient but a battery can provide electricity in areas that do not have electric power distribution
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: it is also useful for things that move such as electric vehicles and mobile phones
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: batteries may be primary or secondary

lines.value: the primary is thrown away when it can no longer provide electricity
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: the secondary can be recharged and reused

lines.value: a battery can be one cell or many cells

lines.value: each cell has an anode cathode and electrolyte

lines.value: it is often a type of acid and can be dangerous to touch

lines.value: light pollution is a type of pollution
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: it is defined as any adverse or bad effect as a result of man made lights usually this means too much light
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: several species including plants and humans are badly affected by light pollution
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: most people have never heard of light pollution and those who have usually don't care or do anything about it
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: light pollution costs americans billions of dollars every year
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: there are five kinds of light pollution sky glow is the kind of light pollution that prevents people from seeing stars and other deep space objects
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: this causes birds to not be able to migrate to the right place because they can not follow the moon and stars
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: sky glow also prevents astronomers from seeing dim objects
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: light trespass is when light being used by a person goes into the property of another
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: although light trespass is not an environmental issue it is still light pollution
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: the third kind of light pollution glare has different kinds
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: the first disability glare is the loss of visibility because of too many lights
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: discomfort glare is when the lights cause pain
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: light pollution stops migrating birds from having any way of seeing the moon and stars that they need to use to navigate the direction of their migration therefore not being able to migrate to the correct place
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: also sea turtles do not come to shore and nest as often because they are afraid of the lights
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: it also affects animals eyes as a flash of camera weakens the eyesight of animals
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: glare causes sleep problems in humans
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: for example too much light in an apartment shining in from a nearby billboard will disturb their sleep
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: also science is being affected by light pollution
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: astronomers have no way of observing or making discoveries with too much light to block the night sky
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: it also causes headaches when light directly falls into our eyes and affects the sensory nerves
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: there are now several groups that are trying to prevent light pollution
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: light pollution first made news in 1964 when an observatory was specially placed just to avoid light pollution
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: however it wasn't brought to the attention of most people until june 6 2002 when the czech republic passed the world's first light pollution law
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: since then light pollution is slowly being recognized by the general public as a major problem
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: also goverment should pay attention for advertisements which produce the greatest amount of light
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: you can lower the amount of light pollution by having lights off when they are not needed
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: you can also shield yourself from this pollution by putting curtains on a window facing the street or any other disturbing light source

lines.value: so i could turn the character of this fat from a chaotic and fluctuating condition to that of a rigid form so i took an extreme position in sculpture and a material that was absolutely fundamental for life and not associated with art."many people believe that this use of felt and fat recalled a plane crash experienced while flying for the luftwaffe in the crimea in the winter of 1942-43

lines.value: basque in basque ) is the language spoken by the basque people in the basque country and diaspora

lines.value: although it is surrounded by indo european languages basque is a language isolate

lines.value: many scholars have tried to link basque to etruscan african languages caucasian languages and so on but most see basque as a language isolate

lines.value: a connection with the iberian language gave some hope but it is unclear whether similarities are due to genetic relations or mere vicinity

lines.value: it consists of five pure vowels,

lines.value: many of the newly rich business people took billions in cash and assets outside of the country
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: the depression of state and economy led to the collapse of social services
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: millions went into poverty from 1.5% level of poverty in the late soviet era to 39 49% by mid 1993
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: the 1990s saw extreme corruption and lawlessness rise of criminal gangs and violent crime
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: the 1990s had many armed conflicts in the north caucasus
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: there were both local ethnic battles and separatist islamist insurrections
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: since the chechen separatists declared independence in the early 1990s a chechen war was fought between the rebel groups and the russian military
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: terrorist attacks against civilians caused hundreds of deaths
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: the most notable of these were the moscow theater hostage crisis and beslan school siege
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: russia took responsibility for settling the ussr's external debts even though its population made up just half of the population of the ussr at the time of its dissolution
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: high budget deficits caused the 1998 russian financial crisis and resulted in further gdp decline
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: on 31 december 1999 president yeltsin resigned or quit being the president
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: the job of president was given to the recently appointed prime minister vladimir putin
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: putin then won the 2000 presidential election
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: putin stopped the chechen rebellion quickly but violence still occurs in the northern caucasus at times
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: high oil prices and initially weak currency followed by increasing domestic demand consumption and investments has helped the economy grow for nine straight years
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: this improved the standard of living and increasing russia's influence on the world stage
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: while many reforms made during the putin presidency have been criticized by western nations as undemocratic putin's leadership led to stability and progress
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: this won him widespread popularity in russia
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: on 2 march 2008 dmitry medvedev was elected president of russia whilst putin became prime minister
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: putin returned to the presidency following the 2012 presidential elections and medvedev was appointed prime minister
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: russia's capital and the biggest city is moscow
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: the second biggest city is saint petersburg which was the capital of russia in the 18th and 19th centuries
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: cities in russia with more than one million people are in order the most western point of russia is near kaliningrad formerly named konigsberg
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: the most eastern point of russia is diomid island 35 km from chukotka russia and from alaska usa

lines.value: the most southern point is in caucasus on the border with azerbaijan

lines.value: the most northern point is on franz josef land archipelago in arctic ocean from the north pole
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: most people 73.7% live in cities

lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: the current population growth is close to zero and the population went down by 0.085% in 2008

lines.value: russia's area is about 17 million square kilometers 6.5 million sq

lines.value: siberia has a very low density
